Great atmosphere and overall restaurant design, however the dishes that we ordered could have been a little better. We got the shishito peppers, char siu bbq pork ribs, African chicken, and hakka noodles. The shishito peppers were kind of bland, could be solved with more seasoning. The bbq char siu pork ribs were a little dry/hard but the overall flavoring was good. The hakka noodles were basically a vegetable lo mien topped with parsley and basil. The African chicken was good but was oriented more towards Thai cuisine because of the coconut curry. The place is on the pricier side hence why I had a higher expectation for the dishes.
The doors in Macao captivated me to stop in for a quick drink! Bartenders are very nice and I like that the chef was around. Cocktails were great

Favorite place to go out in NYC! Dancing bar downstairs is amazing! Philip, Ivan and the crew are incredible! This has become our go-to place when we want to be sure to have a great time - and we always do! Reese is also the best guy ever.

Great food and trendy atmosphere! Macao is dark lit with cool, loud music, which makes it a great Saturday night dinner spot. Probably less romantic and more of a fun dinner. Cocktails were all unique, though on the sweeter and pricier side. We came with a large party so we ordered most of the menu, but my personal favorites were the mushroom & truffle croquettes, kale & chicory salad, sweet corn & edamame dumplings, charred octopus, and Macanese lobster noodles. Food was an interesting Chinese, Portuguese fusion and I did not know what to expect but was pleasantly surprised. Service was fantastic - one of us spilled a cocktail and the waiter immediately replaced it and cleaned the spill. Look forward to coming back here soon!

I stepped out of a steamy New York summer evening into the cool darkness of this Tribeca restaurant and was immediately transported. Such a chill vibe - you really feel like you've stepped into an old Macao outpost from last century. The food is both unique and delicious, a great fusion of Asian influences with a hint of global Portuguese. I grazed off of the appetizers and put together a meal out of the small plates - the chicken and pork belly dumplings, mushroom & truffle croquettes, char sui bbq ribs, etc. They have a fun selection of drinks, too, with a section on the menu devoted to "fancy cocktails." So many interesting choices, you should just order one of the welcome cocktails to tide you over while you try to decide on your second!

This review is from a tipsy, 2am POV. That being said, Macao enabled the night to continue fabulously with great music and a fun scene in the dance box downstairs. Service was prompt and all I remember were the smiles of everyone around me. Given the other reviews related to food, I can't wait to go back and try all the rest that this place has to offer!

You might walk past this one late night, hidden away at 311 Church street. The decor is said to be inspired by a 1940s gambling den with a very high ceiling, dark interior, a few lovely classic chinese paintings. We went Sunday night with a crowd of 7 and it was empty. They are crowded during the business week and charge executive prices. We ordered dishes conservatively - a few entrees and 2 of us had appetizers and my portion of the bill 1/7th was $70. My grilled octopus was tender and delicious. I had prosecco and the table ordered 2 bottles of wine ($50 each!) Wow. The music was 70s booming, neither disco Portuguese or chinese. All in all, ask someone to invite you.

Macao trading company. Went there in a Monday night and it happened to be live music night which was a pleasant surprise. Tasteful soft jazz welcomed us to the beautiful decor and cozy setting. Dumplings are fair. Don't waste a course on them. Brussel Sprout salad is amazing. Crispy fish is excellent. Lobster noodles overrated. Lobster over cooked. Sichuan eggplant was delicious especially when eaten with black coconut rice. Fair service. Cool vibe.

Totally forgot I had previously written a review of this establishment.  Nevertheless, my more recent visit bears mentioning.  Dined at Macao for dinner on a Monday night.  Once again I was not disappointed by the food.  We had the crispy whole fish, african chicken, octopus, dumplings and chocolate torte.  Everything was marvelous.  However, what really takes the cake...or torte...was the live music Macao offers every Monday night.  The music the night we visited was along the lines of French cabaret.  The music, awesome decor and the general ambiance of this place really works to transport one away from the humdrum of the usual Manhattan dining scene (or...maybe it was my drinks???).  In any case, definitely worth visiting on a Monday night!

I really don't understand the high score. The menu is limited. We had ribs to start which were dry and over salted. The lobster in my lobster noodles was fine, but the noodles themselves were the exact taste and consistency of a packet/pot noodle. Really disappointing. Friendly service though.

Go with the bartenders recommendation.

Had a bunch of apps. Food was really good, especially the coconut black rice, although couldn't really taste the coconut. Service very attentive. Nice vibe. Bathroom sink looked like a murder scene. Nice touch!

We found this beautiful spot by happenstance while looking for late night eats coming over from The Roxy Hotel and we are so happy we did. Truly a hidden gem. Amy B. took great care of us & the food was delish. Their late night menu is perfect. We were blown away at how cool & cozy it was while still being eclectic, decorative & current. Great job!

Decor is amazing. Tip: they have downstairs seating but worth waiting for a table upstairs, where you get the full effect of the decor. Our cocktails were delicious ( I had the Bangkok surprise - a tad sweet but very good). Appetizers of fried dumplings and octopus on point. My Hoisin noodles were very tasty. Only disappointment: my husband's wagyu beef - while it was good, the minuscule 4 slices of beef do not justify a $48 price.

My husband and I stumbled to this restaurant. Oh boy we're we surprised by the little gem we had found. Food was amazing!!! Drinks were perfect, and our waitress was Very helpful with helping us decide on our dinner options, she was very knowledgeable on all the plates and drinks! Keep up the great work!!! The atmosphere here is very cozy, but by the bar area very lively. We will definitely be back next time we are in town.

Food was good, a bit greasy. Cocktails seemed off there mark, like not was originally intended from the recipe. The server was good but we we went to pay the over $400 check no itemized receipt was given and we were not informed that the gratuity was added. We thankfully asked for one and caught it ourselves. We usually tip over 20% so it's not the fact that it was added that's industry standard but to not leave a receipt or inform us is super shady. Sad day

I can only review the bar area, drinks, and service provided by the bar tender, Daniel. He was super friendly and professional and made great drinks. Many of the drinks were a fusion of Asian and European/traditional flavors. The dragon's milk was a different drink. After a minute or two, it grew on me and I really enjoyed it. The space is really nice. I will try their food next time I am in the area.

We had an amazing dinner Saturday night at Macao. Frannie was our waitress, and she was FANTASTIC. Extremely knowledgeable, very fun, helpful, guided us in the right direction with our food choices. She took very good care of us, some of the best service I have received in a long time. Having been in the hospitality industry for 10+ years, I can say with confidence that Frannie really wowed us. The food was delicious, the atmosphere was very lively & fun, overall just a great time!  Everything was reasonably priced as well, one of our lower priced dinners in NYC, but the value was high. Afterwards we went to the bar downstairs, and loved the DJ; he knew exactly what he was doing, and never was there a lull in the music that stopped the energy from staying high and keeping everyone dancing. Bartenders were fast, friendly, and ON IT. Great, great job! Thank you!

This place has some great signature drinks and awesome bartenders.  I especially love the dragon's milk.  Be careful, the alcohol sneaks up on you!  They also had a whole fried fish with some house sauce that was to die for.  I will definitely be exploring the menu more at this place.

Service was attentive from the waitress to the busboy. They even remembered to bring a birthday cake without me having to remind them.!

So tonight, Dana and I took my friend and his new girlfriend who just flew in from FL, out to dinner to Macao Trading Co on Church St in SOHO. The place was cute, had a nice charm and the food was actually very good....but ....I was appalled and disappointed that only after 2 hours, despite having a reservation, and ordering over $305 dollars worth in food and drink, was asked to leave to accommodate incoming evening reservations. I expressed my dissatisfaction  and thought it was disgusting customer service. We were all having such a good time, and this certainly changed the mood at the table...for me primarily. The manager did offer to buy a round a drinks at the bar which we then asked to just take it off the bill which he did end up doing. I was very upset though and will certainly not recommend this place, or even consider visiting again. Macao Trading Co....you lost good customers this evening. A shame.

I love coming here! The Drunken Dragon Milk cocktail is my fav. Their menu changes every so often but the food is great. The setting is perfect for a date night.

Came here for a really early snack before a 1030 dinner. Absolutely solid and I cannot wait to try other things on the menu. We split an order of dumplings, half steamed and the other half fried. I was not a fan of the fried as it was definitely not what I was used to. It ended up being deep fried and not pan. The steamed were very good. We also got the Lobster noodles and oh my goodness. I'd come downtown just for that dish. I'd eat it every day if I could. It had an entire tail of lobster sitting on top that was grilled and seemingly, the rest of the lobster was in the noodles. Lots of chunks of perfectly cooked lobster through out. The sauce was super spicy and creamy. Cannot say enough about those noodles! For my cocktail (well I ended up getting 3 of them, that's how delish they were) I got the Yellow Fever. Peachy and full of fresh ginger. Fantastic little place.

One of my favorite spots for a second or third date. Book the basement. Great ambience.

The interior of this place is beautiful - everything is wooden and the ceilings / walls are adorned with antiques of miniature ships and paintings. I really felt like I was in a trading dock or parlor in the early 1900s. The food though was really disappointing. The "African Chicken" with piri piri (what is that?), sesame slaw, and peanut curry sauce was really just chicken with some Asian flavored sauce splattered on it. The "Macanese Lobster Noodle" was two pieces of lobster - you'd think I'd at least get half a lobster for $32 - mixed in with oversalted fermented chili noodles. The popular "Dragon's Milk" that everyone on Yelp is raving about is really just glorified alcoholic coconut purée but the vodka is so strong that you can't taste past it. I guess everyone is too drunk off dragon's milk to realize how overpriced, shitty and half-assed the food is.

Almost a year later, and I'm back at Macao Trading Company--this time just for drinks.  My friends and I stopped here before heading to dinner, and grabbed a couple drinks a piece.  I started with a Drunken Dragon's Milk, as that was a favorite at my last visit.  For my second drink, I chose the Appolonia--solely because the blood orange puree fascinated me.  My friends chose the Gola Lola and Yellow Fever #2 as their first drinks, and finished with the Drunken Dragon's Milk.  If you are looking for something light, choose the DDM.  Our other drinks were INCREDIBLY strong, but artfully crafted by our awesome bartender--so, worth the instant buzz!

In the heart of TriBeCa lies paradise. This restaurant is cool with a capital c. Very nice ambiance with great music to boot. The food was really the definition of cool with a capital c. The African chicken had a fresh peanut curry, coupled with a surprising slaw--again, so fresh. The Brussels sprouts were drizzled in a nectar of the gods--lord knows what was in it. The Bok Choy was simple, tasty, and the ideal complement to the Frenzy of flavor happening on our plate. The cod was fine with a capital f. Not amazing, but again, fresh. We splurged on the rice pudding - 8$--got my child support payment so felt like a treat. Very good. Y'all should come here. If y'all don't, it's your fault xo

Slightly obsessed with this place. The ambiance is awesome, it's straight out of a movie, awesome old school Asian/Portuguese influence; the food is delicious, service is really good, and the drinks are to die for. There's an upstairs bar which is almost always packed and a small restaurant area. If you go on a Thursday-Saturday evening, they will also have the downstairs open. I love the downstairs, it's dark, lit with a bunch of candles, there are a few small tables and small bar and the bartenders are awesome. My favorite food items: mushroom & truffle croquettes, BBQ pork ribs and shrimp mozambique. All I amazing. I ADORE their Drunken Dragon's Milk drink, and their bashful maiden was really good too  If you tell the bartenders what type of liquor you like and the flavor you are looking for, they will throw something together and it will likely be AMAZING. My only minor complaint is, as one would expect, it's not cheap, but a super cool place.

The food here is amazing! They have great creative drinks. Delicious desserts( love those fried donut holes!). Very nice ambiance(Typically dark lighting). The bacon and Shrimp fried rice is sooo damn good you just want to slap someone( but don't!)! The Macanese Noodle dish is soooo upsettingly good it makes you want to do back flips!!( upsetting because you'll eat it too fast and then it's gone). The first 2 times I was there I had the dish was made with lobster( as described on the menu here). However I was just there yesterday and they had it with jumbo prawns and I actually preferred it with the prawns. Either it's made its totally worth the price. It is a bit spicy but I spice doesn't bother me.  Either way, the service is great, the food is awesome. A great place,  worth the trip way downtown.

Sexy vibes, sexy cocktails and sexy bartenders (ask for Papic), Macao will make your obnoxious group birthday dinner a little less painful. Beautiful space with unpretentious food and service, which is not to say their menu offerings aren't sophisticated and delicious. Would bring my white friends and Asian parents here... Which says A LOT.

This was a nice place to hang out late night with pleasant interior decor, strong drinks, prompt attentive service, and what my friends assure me was good food. This place gets 5 stars for two reasons. First, the drinks were tall and strong. Second, the service was quick and attentive. Captain Lou is an excellent drink with a profound ginger bite. While I didn't partake in the food this place had to offer, my friends devoured the offering and said it was delicious.

I visited Macao for the first time last week and have to say it was one of the best meals I have had recently. The interior of the space is dimly lit and stunning. Apparently it is fashioned to look like the brothels and opium dens of 1930's Macao. That definitely comes through, especially when you take a look at the artwork and scandalous figurines that pepper the stairwell to the downstairs speakeasy. Around 7pm on a Friday night there were plenty of seats available, but after 8pm the place really seemed to pick up. The drink list is great and we really enjoyed our cocktails. The favorite at our table was the Bashful Maiden.  Both the food and drink selection seems to be Asian inspired with an exotic twist. We split a number of appetizers and sides including the charred octopus, which was the best I have ever had. It had great texture and wasn't rubbery the way I have had it at some places. Our favorite thing by far were the mushroom and truffle croquettes. It was very difficult not to order more, they are a must!  Service was attentive and we were happy that they accommodated our walk in, despite there being a lot of reservations coming in. I will definitely visit again and would love to come back to the speakeasy for a sexy date night.

We went for Valentines Day and had an 8:30 reservation. Even though most tables were full the hostess graciously gave us a booth at our request. The atmosphere is reminiscent of a smoky dark old world bar in Hong Kong back in the 50s,60s. It is romantic and funky with interesting drinks. I had the Mata Hari a cognac based drink and my Husband had the Bashful Maiden a gin drink. We started with the chicken and pork belly dumplings and the spareribs. Both were delicious and flavorful. We ordered our 2nd round of drinks when Franny our wonderful server informed us that we would have to wait since a health inspector made a surprise visit. They have an A rating which they still have after inspection. They are not allowed to mix cocktails or cook until inspection was completed. We were happy to wait since we were in no rush and it was Valentines Day. After inspection was completed our African Chicken and Veggie Fried rice came out. We split both and the chicken was moist and juicy and I could've eaten the fried rice all day. We ordered the banana split which Franny informed us was on the house cause of the inconvenience! That topped off an already magical evening!!

Chicken and pork belly dumplings were amongst the best you'll have anywhere. The crispy fish was incredible but prawn noodles a touch underwhelming after the dumplings. Jasmine rice pudding was a delight. Drinks also fantastic.

Drunken dragon milk cocktail tasted pretty good but for $15 (+tip): not so sure. Cool pirates of the Caribbean-ey decor. If you like $10 for 4 dumplings you should be happy here. If you are not made of money find some place else to hang out.

column3: Long Island City, New York, NY
column6: Drinks are probably better than the food, and definitely on the pricey side, but the ambience is great and cocktails are second to none.
The burlesque downstairs is fun - consistent delicious food - strong drinks and hot Serbian bartenders!
Great food, service, atmosphere. The fried rice is to die for and Daniello makes a mean drink. This place should not be overlooked.

The Macao Trading Company is a fusion of Portuguese and Asian, and isn't really that representative of Macau's actual cuisine, which is simpler and certainly less diverse. The atmosphere is fun and lively and the cocktails are extremely well made. It makes sense that this is the sister restaurant of Employees Only. The food was excellent, especially the shrimp and the ribs.

Came with a party of 8 on a sat night, the service was good, we tried bacalao, croquettes, dumplings, kale salad, ribs. Everything was good. For entrée , we had steak (a bit dry for medium rear), fried rice, which was very good and a dish similar to paella, which tasted fine. For desert , chocolate cake with chocolate ice cream (it was spicy, we didnt get it) and portugese donuts, were just ok. The drinks were not so good, many tastes like they had too much of sour mix . After diner, we went downstairs. It was crowded and hot, but it was ok for about an hour.  Overall, good experience.
